This condition was annexedlto the agree- ment ; that the Abipones and Mocobios in cap- tivity amongst the Spaniards should be sent home without a ransom, but that the Christian captives should pay a price for their liberty: and numbers did return to Cordoba, Asump· cion and Corrientes, though many of the Spa- nish, Negro, and Guarany captives had be- come so familiarized to the Abipones by long acquaintance, that fearing to lose the liberty they enjoyed amongst these people, even whilst in a state of servitude, they would on no account return to their own country. In the town of St. Jeronymo alone forty-seven of each sex remained voluntary captives, but, more intolerable than the savages themselves, they were a pest to the new colonies, a hind- rance to religion, the torment of the Fathers, devisers of frauds and wickedness; in short, Os such a character, that except baptism, which they received in their infancy, they retained nothing of Christianity.
